Suppose that <math display="inline">\left( \Gamma, \theta \right)</math> is a rule of inference. Then <math display="block">\Gamma \models \theta</math>

== Proof ==

* Supposing that <math display="inline">\left( \Gamma, \theta \right) </math> is a [[Rule of Inference (Propositional Consequence)|rule of type PC]]. Then by the fact that [[Propositional Consequence Equivalence|a propositional consequence is equivalent to a tautology]]: <math display="block">\left[ \gamma_{1P} \land  \gamma_{2P} \land  \ldots \land \gamma _{\left( n-1 \right)P} \land  \gamma_{nP} \right] \to \theta_P</math>is a tautology, where we set <math display="inline">\Gamma_P=\left\{ \gamma_{1P} ,  \gamma_{2P}, \ldots , \gamma _{\left( n-1 \right)P} ,  \gamma_{nP} \right\}</math> (the set of propositional formulas corresponding to <math display="inline">\Gamma</math>) and <math display="inline">\theta_P</math> the propositional formula corresponding to <math display="inline">\theta</math>.
* Since the propositional version of the rule is a tautology, we know that:<math display="block">\left[ \gamma_1\land \gamma_2\land  \ldots\land \gamma_{n-1}\land \gamma_{n} \right] \to \theta</math>[[Tautology to Validity|is valid]], therefore for any <math display="inline">\mathcal{L}-\text{structure}</math> <math display="inline">\mathfrak{A}</math>, and assignment function <math display="inline">s</math>. We have <math display="inline">\mathfrak{A} \models \left(\left[ \gamma_1\land \gamma_2\land  \ldots\land \gamma_{n-1}\land \gamma_{n} \right] \to \theta\right)\left[ s \right]</math>
** By definition that says, whenever <math display="inline">\mathfrak{A} \models \left[ \gamma_1\land \gamma_2\land  \ldots\land \gamma_{n-1}\land \gamma_{n} \right]\left[ s \right]</math>, then we have <math display="inline">\mathfrak{A} \models \theta\left[ s \right]</math> and so <math display="inline">\Gamma \models \theta</math> as required.
